required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effects of Apomorphine on Experimental and Clinical Pain in Patients With Chronic Radicular Pain
clinical_study.official_title: The Effects of the Dopamine Agonist (Apomorphine) on Experimental and Clinical Pain in Patients With Chronic Radicular Pain: a Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Cross-over Study

brief_summary.textblock: The study aimed to explore the effect of the dopamine agonist apomorphine on spontaneous pain intensity and evoked cold clinical and experimental pain in patients with lumbar radicular neuropathic pain (NP). Patients received either apomorphine or placebo in a randomized double-blinded manner.

detailed_description.textblock:
Although evidence suggests that dopaminergic systems are involved in pain processing, the efficacy of dopaminergic interventions in reducing pain remains questionable. This randomized, double blinded, placebo-controlled, cross-over study was aimed to explore the effect of the dopamine agonist apomorphine on spontaneous pain intensity and evoked cold clinical and experimental pain in patients with lumbar radicular neuropathic pain (NP).
Data was collected from 35 patients (18 men, mean age 56.2Â±13.1 years). The following five pain measures were tested before (baseline) and 30, 75 and 120 min subsequent to subcutaneous injection of 1.5 mg apomorphine or placebo in two separate sessions: spontaneous pain intensity, threshold and tolerance to cold pain in the most painful site in the affected leg and in a remote healthy site in the dominant hand.

primary_outcome.measure: Experimental and clinical cold pain tolerance measured in seconds
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 120 minutes after drug administration

secondary_outcome.measure: Experimental and clinical cold pain threshold measured in seconds
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 120 minutes after drug administration

secondary_outcome.measure: Spontaneous clinical pain intensity measured on a numeric pain scale (NPS, 0-100)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 120 minutes after drug administration

responsible_party.investigator_title: Head of pain research unit, Institute of pain

patient_data.ipd_description: Individual participant data will not be shared.
